2038. Hallam, Isabella (Mrs. B.B.)
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: MRS. B.B. HALLAM

Present Address: C.A.R.I.

Pioneer Address: SASK.

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1905

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE:

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realise that not one person will be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Flower Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

2. How many of these were bachelor houses?

3. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (Give as much detail as possible.)

4. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? (Give details.)

5. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

6. What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

7. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

8. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?

9. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

10. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

11. Did you ever have "meets" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? (Give details.)

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "meets" were for, and how often they occurred.

12. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. (Give dates.)

13. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. (Give details.)

14. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

No. 5

Flower Recreation and Social Life.

MERRILY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 

How many of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (Give no rush.)

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Lunch days.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take pot-luck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If so, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had interrupted in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have "bless" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "grees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. No.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. After 1914

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? 

Danced every two weeks in local school.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, games, etc., if you have not described those on the school Christmas list.) Give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses, or halls (as referred to in Question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

If you have not done the above on the school Christmas tree, please state.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

How were babies and small children provided for?

What dances were popular?

12. What attempts at formality, or "manners," do you remember in small towns, such as glancing out when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc., etc.? Write.

13. Was the obituary known in your community? If so, describe what you remember about obituaries, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? How many women belonged? How often did it meet? What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? If so, when was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

All ate at a long table each family bringing their own food.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

Sandwiches, salad, cake & pie.
